title: Still have to pay if you cancel

review:
My biggest gripe is that the program puts a badge on the icon, and when you open the program to see what the badge represented, there are ZERO, NADA, NO indications why the program put a badge on the icon. If your going to put a badge on the icon, at least have a clear reason why displayed when the user opens the program.
It’s like I’m the mouse being offered the piece of cheese and then it’s yanked away, or the horse being teased by a carrot on a string. I must click the icon to find the prize within the app that doesn’t exist.

Stay safe and get your real brain Impulse", 'modified': '2023-07-21T10:11:08Z'}
review: I downloaded this app because I saw quite a few ads about it on Tiktok. I used the free trial to do a test run and here’s what i’ve decided. The app is absolutely not worth the David Hasselhoff that comes with it. The games are copies of free games you can easily download in the app store. The quizzes are useless because you can’t view the full report without a yearly subscription. This app seems to prey on people’s insecurities relative to mental capacity and it’s disturbing. Save your time & don’t bother. This app is a lackluster compilation of elements you can locate on the internet for free with a simple search.
title: Not worth the trouble

review:
I love the app so far. Great fun games that are just the right amount of challenge to be fun but feel like you’re working your brain for them. Cool tests too, to lead about yourself! I bought the subscription and have played every day.
It’s also not so addicting like other phone games that you don’t want to put it down. I can easily take a 5 or 10 minute break to play and go back to my work.
title: So far so good!

Stay safe and get your real brain Impulse", 'modified': '2023-07-26T08:25:03Z'}
review: I have a neurological condition called Wernicke’s Encephalopathy. It affects the way I remember information and a lot of my memory is based on strong emotions. So if something makes me very nervous, excited, mad, happy, sad then I typically remember it. But everyday things like medications, appointments, showers, and etc. just slip. This app has given me a tool to practice and work on my memory in small ways! I love it and enjoy it very much.
title: Great for Concentration and Memory

Stay safe and get your real brain Impulse", 'modified': '2023-09-18T11:50:02Z'}
review:
I’m torn between a 3 and a 4 star rating. I really do love the games, but the awful saving is almost gamebreaking. 

I’ve done over 650 levels of the candy sorting, but a lot of them say I haven’t beat the level (which of course I did, otherwise I wouldn’t have been able to move forward). I completed a level a couple days ago that was a harder one than usual and took a few days of me coming back to it until I eventually got it. I then did a few levels after that one, no problem. 

Except now I’ve lost that progress, and I’m back to this awful level.

I’m a completionist. I want all the levels to have a pretty green checkmark, but if I go back to a level that didn’t save to give it the checkmark, then the level after that one no longer has a checkmark. 

Make it make sense.
title: Lots of great, fun games and levels - not great saving

review: I'm enjoying this game quite a bit. It can provide me with insights into myself and my thought patterns while also allowing me to work on areas that I want to improve upon within my mind. review:
Many of us have played various games on our phones for fun. This app makes an excellent choice of games that are fun in many ways while also engaging in ways that I’ve found myself lacking compared to when I’ve previously done them as a kid. 

Excellent concept of an app, and one that I believe is beneficial versus many of the other time wasters that occupy our screen time.

review: Honestly, I enjoy ranking in the top percentile because I’ve always felt like I was little smarter than most people and these brain teasers confirm that. Really cool self reflective app.

review: Love this app and get to play all the brainy games I love the most. I’ve deleted all my other apps like this. It gives you workouts and you can play whichever ones you want aside from that. review:
1. I’m always looking for little fun puzzle games but get quickly bored of playing the same game and puzzles over and over again which honestly most games on my phone last maybe a week before I ever open it again, this one is great because you always get a new game!

2. Challenges increase based on your own ability to complete so it won’t get too difficult too quick but for games you excel at they will increase the difficulty for that single game.

3. You can go in after daily challenges and play levels on any game you enjoy.

4. They are all games that will help with mental status, increasing multiple different regions of your brain and can be adjusted to however you want.
title: Perfect game

title: Great exercises for brain

review: After utilizing the free trial period for Impulse, I had NO doubt that it was worth the purchase price. If you enjoy puzzles and brain games, you need to try the app that conveniently houses all the different kinds of brain teasers and brain training exercises in one easy to use package.  Like any other body part, the brain needs working out too, and this app employees so many different types of mental challenges and problem to solve, it's like cross-training for your brain.
title: Impulse App

review: I wanted to give it a try because I wanted to see if I could do the drawing activity in the advertisement. Went to my Apple subscriptions and there is no way to cancel the trial. If that wasn’t bad enough, I already got notification from my payment method that they requested the money for the subscription.  Now I have to deal with Apple to figure out how to cancel the trial and not get the subscription charged. There’s no way to cancel the trial, so just don’t download until they fix it.

I would suggest every parent give this to their kids!

review: I have experienced few apps that come for your coin quite as insidiously as this one. "Want an IQ test report? Subscribe! Don't want to subscribe? How about a one time discount purchase? ARE YOU SURE?!" Never seen an app push notify you (and I'm pretty sure I didn't accept notifications) after you cancel the subscription and ask for feedback. But cancelling is just one of many ways to get a >90% discount if you're willing to sign up for a whole year. The games are fun, if you can ignore the grubby asks.
title: Fun app clawing for coin

review: You’d think there would just be boring tests but no! There are three games that are assigned each day. I do mine in the morning so I can get my brain ready for the day. And after that you can pick! There are also tests but they aren’t all boring and you don’t have to do them. You can see which side of your brain is dominate. This is a very great app. You should definitely try it out.

review: I have a lot of gray matter apparently from extensive Adderall use for over 10 years. Which has made me a much happier person.
title: Adderall damage reversal

review:
This is a quality group of intelligent games that are good for your mind to test your skills, sharpen your thinking, and just have fun. 

I love seeing how I do compared to others and compared to my previous scores. This does a great job at both. 

I am sick of all the fake, click bait apps out there. The ads are rarely as they advertise. Nice to find one that does what it says and does it well.
title: Not Click Bait, LoL

Stay tuned and get your real brain Impulse.", 'modified': '2019-08-02T06:08:41Z'}
review:
I saw an ad for this app. I clicked through to check it out. The free trial allows you one day of “games/tests” after that you with have to watch long ads on each test or buy the premium for like 6 or 7 bucks a month. 

I completed the first and second days and a few extra games. They were interesting, but certainly not worth buying a full version of the app on a subscription basis. Please before you ask for 4 bucks a month less than Netflix. Provide something that has at least 1/10th of its value. 

I would not recommend this app at its current pricing.
title: Good idea, bad execution

{'id': 37335423, 'body': "Hello,

Thank you for your feedback, we truly appreciate it.

We're sorry to hear that your experience did not meet your expectations. 

We're committed to improving our app and would greatly value your unique perspective. If you have any suggestions or ideas on how we can enhance the user experience, please don't hesitate to email us at support@brainimpulse.me.

Stay safe and get your real brain Impulse", 'modified': '2023-06-26T13:05:08Z'}
review:
This app is unbelievable. Make no mistake, this app doesn’t improve your memory or anything else it claims to do. 

The games are all unbelievably simple, and serve only as a nice little dopamine hit, a little pat on the head for completing petty little tasks. In exchange for giving you your little reward, all they ask is little monthly subscription fee.

This isn’t a brain trainer. It’s more akin to a slot machine, where you pay to receive a “Good Job!” rather than a chance at winning money. It saddens me that they can sell you such a thinly veiled farce, and saddens me more that so many people buy it.
title: An Horrific Lie

Stay safe and get your real brain Impulse", 'modified': '2023-09-15T13:00:28Z'}
review: Just another “free” app where you get into it and start trying things out then you get hit with a payment wall. You waste your time taking their quizzes just to get to the end and find out you have to pay MONTHLY to see your results. Who wants to pay for a subscription on an app? Just charge for the app itself and your numbers just might go up. With all the streaming services milking us for our money, most can’t afford to hand another app more money every month.
title: App is free, but content is not.

review: Eh, I was interested and gave it a whirl. Even at the start of a free three day trial you get pressured at every turn to subscribe for a year. Then you “win” a gift for completing a game- guess what? It’s a discount for a subscription! Leave that screen and try one of the tests. Finish the test and the results are blocked unless you pay for a year. Yeah decline, but wait- now it offers to sell you the results for the low, low price of $4 (or whatever it was). Basically, the thing feels like a scam, and it’s getting deleted stat.

review: Games are fun and challenging, but when it comes how you compare to others in your age group, it laughably bad. You’re either better than 99% of your peers or zero percent. Also, figuring out how to cancel or modify your subscription is so difficult it is bordering on fraud. There are a lot better games out there for same amount of money. Choose wisely

review: It can be hard to find a game suitable for OCD, ADHD, and autism. This game showcases the different impulses the brain desires. Usually I have to have music, a show, or a movie in the background, and i go from tik tok to instagram to one of my many app games and none of them suit my needs. But this way I can have everything and just switch within the game!!! 10/10

review:
Anytime you make a game that puts you against a clock ….for most folks causes an increased stress response. I’m not paying for something that left me worse off than when I started. Then your test results are shown against the same population of people and it shows you where you rank. Sometimes you’re 98% better than those of the same age group - sometimes only 8%.
So now you feel anxious and stupid. Lol no thanks - I can go to work and get laid for that!
title: Gotta pay and it gives me anxiety

review: My memory has improved since doing daily exercises and my computations are no longer delayed !  I’ve always loved challenging brain teasers but this one in particular has help me become more balanced hemisphere wise. So it’s worth the fee that you pay to play fun games. And improve concentration, memory and comprehension skills.
title: Effective!

review:
I have become pretty hooked on the crossword game, and find the challenges and puzzles engaging and fun.

It has become very clear through the crossword game that whoever is responsible for creating the puzzles has a strong religious background, based on the word choice and the words not deemed words (as bonuses).  In this day and age I find that a bit heavy handed and would have given a higher rating were it not for that.
title: Engaging app, but would prefer less religious bias

developerResponse:
{'id': 26027963, 'body': "Hi there,

Thanks for the feedback, we appreciate it a lot.

We would be truly happy to provide everyone with more free features and content, however, as of now, premium access and ads is a way to support further App development. We'll work hard to change that as soon as possible.

Please skip the ads you see after 5-7 sec. All of them are skippable, just close them when the 'X' arrives on the screen.

By the way, there is a limited time offer available with 92% off for the yearly plan (if compared with a regular weekly subscription). So just for the price of a few cups of coffee, you'll get full access to the premium content and remove all ads.

review: You RARELY ever play a game here. It’s literally ad after ad after ad after ad after ad, 30 second game, ad, ad, ad, ad and another ad. What’s worse is the ads are all at least 30 seconds, some a minute, and when they finish they wait another 20 seconds or so before you even can click the X to exit the ad and bring up the next ad. Then some other ads don’t even have an X show up, they force you to click on it in order to get to the next screen. This is just an advertising app, nothing good.

review: I signed up for the free trial to test out the app. This did open quite a range of things for me to try out - it’s quite enjoyable. Among them, an IQ test. This was a 60 question/ 20 min test and, at the end, it gave a score.  I could see the score but would only allow me to access the report if I signed up for an ongoing membership. This immediately turned me off.  What is the purpose of a free trial if I cannot access portions of the app? What else would I have to pay extra for even if I signed up for an ongoing subscription? Immediately canceled my free trial.

review: I switched from Elevate to Impulse recently and while Impulse has a larger variety of problem solving games, Elevate gives you tips if you’re struggling on a game. developerResponse:
{'id': 39773782, 'body': "Hello,

Thank you for your feedback, we truly appreciate it.

Please be aware that a premium subscription isn't a requirement. You may watch some ads to unlock new exercises, games and workout days. Stay safe and get your real brain Impulse", 'modified': '2023-09-12T10:15:31Z'}
review: If this is brain training then so is candy crush. Slapping the title brain training on some games a child could play and telling your audience that they are "better than 90% of their piers!" is genius. 30 question IQ test, 25 question AHDH diagnosis. Yeah right. If this is what you settle for, then the TV remote and microwave buttons are also brain training for numbers and calculation. Maybe social media scroll is brain training. I'm doing spelling training typing a review. If only I could watch some ads or pay money to have someone pat me on the back for it.
title: Training for what?

review: I am always wanting to challenge my brain especially not working a day job! It’s great to keep my brain sharp! But I like how it tells me how I match up to my peers! It’s a good guideline on how much I can improve or to impress myself on how good i’m doing! I know people always say never compare yourself but I think they do it in a gentle way!
title: Fun to Compare

Stay safe and get your real brain Impulse", 'modified': '2023-07-19T13:46:05Z'}
review: They trap you by making you sign up for their “free” 3 day trial. Then it automatically charges you if you do not cancel it. However there is no quick and painless way to cancel the subscription at this time. You have to jump through hoops and give your left Thumb to even figure how to begin to cancel it. NOT an Honest App. I’d rather have a true free trial and then if I like it hit a button to keep it. Beware of apps like this, they are banking on you forgetting or getting frustrated and just paying for it.
title: It’s a trap. To many hoops, and no easy way to cancel.

This is now part of my every day workout routine.

Stay safe and get your real brain Impulse", 'modified': '2023-09-12T10:16:13Z'}
review:
Yeah, I’ve had this app for a few weeks now, found it just searching through the App Store.

Since installing it I’ve been bombarded with ads on Facebook that are completely irrelevant to what is actually in the app, the final straw was an ad where it implied there was some sort of personality quiz that would determine your “Male Archetype” whatever that means.

Not only was said ad irrelevant to the actual content in the app, it was completely nonsensical. It was a graph with the different “male archetypes” with several personality traits that said “male archetypes” have in varying degrees.

I’m not going to go through all of them, but “The creator” “male archetype” had one of, if not the lowest score in creativity.

I have no idea what their intention with these ads are, but if it’s to get people who already use your app to delete it, then good job it worked.
title: Irrelevant nonsense ads

review: Parents should be aware that Impulse is a highly kid-friendly puzzle game with a low entrance barrier that offers a natural introduction to the physics of mass, velocity, and trajectory without being overtly didactic. review: The challenges are designed to exercise different parts of the brain and consistent practice helps me think and deduct ideas faster. Interestingly enough, I noticed a byproduct of this practice. Working on these exercises “light a fire” in my overall state of mind so it shifting me out of a sadness, depression or any lower state to a higher, brighter mood.

review: I downloaded this game because I saw it on tiktok I kinda knew it was going to ask for money for a trial and all that and It did. But it’s been amazing there’s still so many games open for playing and tips and information. I love it so much and it’s definitely entertaining for my adhd

review: I don’t even write these things but I was incensed just enough to do so, this is a great app I just wish it included the family share option for the amount of money you’re paying for the annual subscription. Otherwise 90% better than DOOM Scrolling (although you’d do even better outside touching grass and writing poetry in longhand)
title: Great but lacks

review: I got this app to help stretch my brain and improve my brain function in day to day life. Although it may seem like a bunch of kid games it actually is semi-challenging, but not in a way that makes you want to quit. I also heard keeping your brain active can prevent dementia so this app would be a good way to do that.
title: I love it!

review: Enjoying the app so far. Definitely gets your brain going and stimulated. I would like to see more depth on how I compare to my peers in the progress section. Not quite grasping that part, but otherwise I’m making this app a daily part of my day and enjoy it a lot.
title: Still very new at this

review: So, the games are calming to me- my brain enjoys the fodder not attached to gem like candies. I like that most of the games are going to reinforce skills needed every day! Memory / recall puzzles of all kinds, math skills- money,  simple math. I enjoy the independence of going at my own pace, and there is no penalty here- no lost points, level, etc.
title: Life skills- great games

review:
I love this because it is a game with a purpose. I know I am struggling with memory and have two parents with Alzheimer’s issues. I wish I knew about this for them. 
It’s fun educating and targeted on just what I need. Fun Functionally Targeted Memory sit ups for the brain. When and Where will the Memory Olympics begin
title: Memory Games save mind

review: After having a “mini stroke” due to complications from a vaccine, I have been suffering from a number of health issues, including brain fog, and uncoordinated typing. This program has been helpful in both monitoring, assessing, and training to improve my condition.
title: Very helpful after medical problem

review: I love this app. It’s like a little sliver of fun mid day :) I especially like the impulse games and the one where you have to put all the same candies in one slot. And also the IQ test has these matching games that I really enjoyed. I wonder how accurate those results were though.. I’d like to put it on my resume. 😆
title: So much fun

This is a wonderful game. Maybe the challenge I’ve been searching for.

Stay safe and get your real brain Impulse.', 'modified': '2022-05-10T06:36:58Z'}
review:
I’ve tried several “brain games” and as a 57 year old that would like to keep my brain sharp, this has been the best app I’ve found, to date.

Instead of the same old repetitive game, playing over and over, this game takes you through different stages, focusing on several different factions of the brain that decrease with age.

It’s far more entertaining and effective than just doing the daily newspaper crossword or “logic puzzles”.

If you are starting to “age” or just want to keep your brain sharp, I’d highly recommend downloading this app and putting it to use!
title: Brain Games

{'id': 35627081, 'body': "Hi there,

Please note on a free or trial plan, you'll still get an access to your results (e.g., an IQ score), but without any further details - these are available to premium users only.

We would be truly happy to provide everyone with more free features and content, however, as of now, premium access is a way to support further App development. We'll work hard to change that as soon as possible.

Stay safe and get your real brain Impulse.", 'modified': '2023-03-28T06:55:05Z'}
review:
Came up as an ad on another app, and thought I’d give it a try. CANNOT EVEN TRY OUT THE TESTS WITHOUT AGREEING TO PAY FOR MEMBERSHIP. To make it worse, when I found out there was no way to access the results without paying, and I tried to exit, they proceeded to bombard me with “are you sure” messages, attempting to get me to access the results of the one test for a “One time fee of 4.99” 
How cheap can you be? I was hoping this app would help me with my mental health, but it has only made me more frustrated. This is terrible.
title: Severely disappointed

Stay safe and get your real brain Impulse", 'modified': '2023-08-07T15:00:38Z'}
review: It's an interesting idea for an app. But at the end of the day it's just a cash grab, capitalizing on the people who need more reassurance in their life. Psychology is a very broad spectrum, and 72 questions and answers ran through an algorithm simply isn't enough to give you a detailed understanding of how your brain and emotions work. Maybe a very slight understanding. But all in all, this app is about as useful as those Facebook quizzes that tell you what superhero you'd be.
title: Interesting idea

Stay tuned and get your real brain Impulse.", 'modified': '2020-01-08T07:58:48Z'}
review:
At first glance this app appears to be something of interest. Unfortunately following the download the user is faced with several prompts requesting that you sign up for upgrades for rather expensive fees.  This happen before you are able to even test out the product.  

At one point it states that you can have a free trial, but will automatically be billed shortly there after.  

I was not even able to explore what this app had to offer before I felt compelled to erase it from my phone, for fear that my account will be charged for something I DO NOT. 

There is no way to cancel and I’m still unsure if my account is going to be billed.  

There are several layers of deception.  I strongly advise all users to pay close attention during the download process.  As for my close friends, I will strongly advise them to avoid this app completely.
title: Very Deceptive

Stay safe and get your real brain Impulse", 'modified': '2023-09-20T09:00:02Z'}
review:
Enjoyed it at first and felt the subscription was worth it. Ultimately got bored of the repetition and got a little lazy so I let it sit for a while. 

Finally got back to it and the daily puzzles were among my least favorite. Either way, I didn’t finish all 5 games, thinking it would reset the next day. 7 days in a row and it’s still the same 5 games. Over and over. 

I get that there’s a training aspect and I’m
probably getting these games because I score lower on them but sometimes it’s because I don’t care enough to focus. No amount of motivation will get me to apply myself when swiping arrow directions.

Canceled my subscription.
title: Was good until it wasn’t

Stay safe and get your real brain Impulse", 'modified': '2023-09-18T11:53:20Z'}
review: I was charged for an entire year of subscription after two days of my three day trial period. On top of that the information given said 6.99 per week unless cancelled, not a year at once. AND the app gifted me 90% off and never reflected that in the payment it took out early. I am now in the process of requesting a refund. I feel like this is a scam hoping people will say “oh well it’s only 30 bucks, I’ll just cancel now and not fight it.” Highly unethical.
title: Be careful!

review:
Signed up for a 3 day “unlimited access” trial just to find out that it won’t even give test results without a paid subscription. For that reason alone, I’m out.  

Update to dev response: when you have an “unlimited access trial” the assumption is that you have full access to the results. The trial is a preview of what you would have if you pay. Why would I pay when the “unlimited access trial” is limited? Maybe update how you advertise that.
title: Don’t trust the trial

review: The instructions are easy to understand, but just when you start to think it might me too simplistic, a change in cadence may catch you by surprise!  This is good exercise for the mind.

It is reasonable to expect that the sample portion of an app includes at least SOME of the many tests you promote in your many, many ads. Sadly, this is not the case. IMHO, this is scammy and deceptive. (This review is based upon the MANY tries I’ve given the app based on different ads FEATURING different tests).

 - you may watch some ads to open new games and workout days;

review: I had understood the subscription was $9.99/month; it is in fact $9.99 per WEEK. Which is ridiculous! Again, it’s a good app, but way too costly and I had thought I was paying for a monthly subscription of $9.99, not a weekly one. Ouch.
title: Deceptive / over expensive

Stay safe and get your real brain Impulse", 'modified': '2023-07-05T11:45:05Z'}
review:
They advertise quizzes but at every turn they want you to get their craziest newest deal for their yearly subscription. You will then find you can’t even take the quizzes even if your subscribe with a free trial

For an app that is designed to help cope and mitigate the symptoms of ADHD, seems like this app is intentionally capitalizing on its weaknesses. For example they give you shining present animations with newer deals, and when you try to reject it the App guilts you.

This is absolutely a psychological ploy to give you a burst of dopamine and then fear of missing out, and take money from those who may have poor impulse control.

Honestly disgusting, what the business is doing with this app isn’t just bad, it’s actively malicious.
title: Do not bother downloading, this app is a money grab

{'id': 39911946, 'body': "Hello,

Thank you for your feedback, we truly appreciate it.

Please be aware that on a free or trial plan, you will still have access to basic results only, such as your IQ score, trauma response type, archetype, ADHD type, etc. However, more detailed information is available exclusively to the users that either subscribed to the yearly/lifetime plan or at least made a payment for the weekly one.

We genuinely wish we could offer more features and content for free, but currently, the premium access and ads help support the continuous development of the app. Rest assured, we're working diligently to change this as soon as possible.

We're committed to improving our app and would greatly value your unique perspective. If you have any suggestions or ideas on how we can enhance the user experience, please don't hesitate to email us at support@brainimpulse.me.

Stay safe and get your real brain Impulse", 'modified': '2023-11-03T10:36:38Z'}
review: You cannot do anything in this app without a subscription. Find a quiz you want to take? That said, kudos to marketing - I was the idiot who clicked the link into this hellhole in the first place.

review: I saw an Impulse ad/ invitation on Instagram to take a personality test. When I looked for more info, I realized I needed to sign up for the free trial in order to take the test. So I signed up for the free trial and took their test, answering 72 questions. Only THEN was I informed I would need to pay for an upgraded subscription (??) just to see my test results. What a scam. Why not tell me that before? Because you want free user data, hm? This app has a real slimy vibe.

Stay safe and get your real brain Impulse", 'modified': '2023-07-07T11:30:34Z'}
review: This app tries to take advantage of people with impulse control disorder. Everyone scores high on their simple IQ test, and their ADHD assessment is an absolute waste of time. It could only be considered fun if you like winning simple games to feel better about yourself. Be careful. The 3 day free trial requires a 24 hour notice of cancellation before they bill you, thereby becoming only a two day trial. This was created by a grifter who likes to prey on people seeking mental strengthening exercises.
title: Snake Oil

review: This app charges for every thing it offers.
